# Cuban Missile Crisis

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

"Missile Crisis" redirects here. For the Cyprus Missile Crisis, see [Cyprus
Missile Crisis](/wiki/Cyprus_Missile_Crisis "Cyprus Missile Crisis").

Cuban Missile Crisis  
---  
Part of the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War")  
[![Soviet-R-12-nuclear-ballistic
missile.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Soviet-R-12-nuclear-

(naval blockade of Cuba ended November 20, 1962)  
---|---  
Location | [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba")  
Result | 

  * Withdrawal of the Soviet Union's nuclear missiles from Cuba
  * Withdrawal of American nuclear missiles from [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey") and [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy")
  * Agreement with the Soviet Union that the United States would never invade Cuba without direct provocation
  * Creation of a [nuclear hotline](/wiki/Moscow%E2%80%93Washington_hotline "Moscow–Washington hotline") between the United States and the Soviet Union

Casualties and losses  
64 Soviet citizens dead (statistics of the [MoD of the RF](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_\(Russia\) "Ministry of Defence \(Russia\)") for 1962—1964)[1] | 1 [U-2](/wiki/Lockheed_U-2 "Lockheed U-2") spy aircraft lost  
1 aircraft damaged  
1 killed  
  
The **Cuban Missile Crisis** , also known as the **October Crisis** (Spanish:
_Crisis de Octubre_), the **Caribbean Crisis**
([Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): Карибский кризис,
[tr.](/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian "Romanization of Russian") _Karibsky
krizis_ , IPA: [[kɐˈrʲipskʲɪj ˈkrʲizʲɪs]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian
"Help:IPA/Russian")), or the **Missile Scare** , was a 13-day (October 16–28,
1962) confrontation between the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United
States") and the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") concerning
American [ballistic missile](/wiki/Ballistic_missile "Ballistic missile")
deployment in [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy") and [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey")
with consequent Soviet ballistic missile deployment in [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba
"Cuba"). The confrontation is often considered [the
closest](/wiki/List_of_nuclear_close_calls "List of nuclear close calls") the
[Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") came to escalating into a full-scale
[nuclear war](/wiki/Nuclear_warfare "Nuclear warfare").[2]

In response to the failed [Bay of Pigs Invasion](/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion
"Bay of Pigs Invasion") of 1961 and the presence of American [Jupiter
ballistic missiles](/wiki/PGM-19_Jupiter "PGM-19 Jupiter") in Italy and
Turkey, Soviet leader [Nikita Khrushchev](/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev "Nikita
Khrushchev") decided to agree to Cuba's request to place nuclear missiles on
the island to deter a future invasion. An agreement was reached during a
secret meeting between Khrushchev and [Fidel Castro](/wiki/Fidel_Castro "Fidel
Castro") in July 1962 and construction of a number of [missile launch
facilities](/wiki/Missile_launch_facility "Missile launch facility") started
later that summer.

The [1962 United States elections](/wiki/United_States_elections,_1962 "United
States elections, 1962") were under way, and the White House had for months
denied charges that it was ignoring dangerous Soviet missiles 90 miles (140
km) from Florida. The missile preparations were confirmed when an Air Force
[U-2 spy plane](/wiki/Lockheed_U-2 "Lockheed U-2") [produced clear
photographic evidence](/wiki/Aerial_reconnaissance#Cold_War "Aerial
reconnaissance") of [medium-range (SS-4)](/wiki/SS-4_Sandal "SS-4 Sandal") and
[intermediate-range (R-14) ballistic missile](/wiki/R-14_Chusovaya "R-14
Chusovaya") facilities. The U.S. established a military blockade to prevent
further missiles from reaching Cuba; Oval Office tapes during the crisis
revealed that Kennedy had also put the blockade in place as an attempt to
provoke Soviet-backed forces in Berlin as well. It announced that they would
not permit offensive weapons to be delivered to Cuba and demanded that the
weapons already in Cuba be dismantled and returned to the Soviet Union.

After a long period of tense negotiations, an agreement was reached between
U.S. President [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy") and
Khrushchev. Publicly, the Soviets would dismantle their offensive weapons in
Cuba and return them to the Soviet Union, subject to [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") verification, in exchange for
a U.S. public declaration and agreement to avoid invading Cuba again.
Secretly, the United States also agreed that it would dismantle all U.S.-built
[Jupiter MRBMs](/wiki/PGM-19_Jupiter "PGM-19 Jupiter"), which had been
deployed in Turkey against the Soviet Union; there has been debate on whether
or not Italy was included in the agreement as well.

When all offensive missiles and [Ilyushin Il-28](/wiki/Ilyushin_Il-28
"Ilyushin Il-28") light bombers had been withdrawn from Cuba, the blockade was
formally ended on November 21, 1962. The negotiations between the United
States and the Soviet Union pointed out the necessity of a quick, clear, and
direct communication line between Washington and Moscow. As a result, the
[Moscow–Washington hotline](/wiki/Moscow%E2%80%93Washington_hotline
"Moscow–Washington hotline") was established. A series of agreements reduced
US-Soviet tensions for several years.

## Earlier US
actions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Earlier US actions")]

The U.S. was concerned about an expansion of [communism](/wiki/Communism
"Communism"), and a [Latin American](/wiki/Latin_American "Latin American")
country openly allying with the Soviet Union was regarded by it as
unacceptable since the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War
II"), and the start of the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"). Such an
involvement would also directly defy the [Monroe
Doctrine](/wiki/Monroe_Doctrine "Monroe Doctrine"), a U.S. policy limiting
U.S. involvement in European colonies and European affairs but holding that
the [Western Hemisphere](/wiki/Western_Hemisphere "Western Hemisphere") was in
the U.S. [sphere of influence](/wiki/Sphere_of_influence "Sphere of
influence").

The Kennedy administration had been publicly embarrassed by the failed [Bay of
Pigs Invasion](/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion "Bay of Pigs Invasion") in May 1961,
which had been launched under President [John F.
Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy") by [CIA](/wiki/CIA
"CIA")-trained forces of [Cuban exiles](/wiki/Cuban_exile "Cuban exile").
Afterward, former President [Dwight Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_Eisenhower
"Dwight Eisenhower") told Kennedy that "the failure of the Bay of Pigs will
embolden the Soviets to do something that they would otherwise not do."[3]:10
The half-hearted invasion left Soviet premier [Nikita
Khrushchev](/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev "Nikita Khrushchev") and his advisers with
the impression that Kennedy was indecisive and, as one Soviet adviser wrote,
"too young, intellectual, not prepared well for decision making in crisis
situations... too intelligent and too weak."[3] U.S. covert operations against
Cuba continued in 1961 with the unsuccessful [Operation
Mongoose](/wiki/Operation_Mongoose "Operation Mongoose").[4]

In addition, Khrushchev's impression of Kennedy's weaknesses was confirmed by
the President's response during the [Berlin Crisis of
1961](/wiki/Berlin_Crisis_of_1961 "Berlin Crisis of 1961"), particularly to
the building of the [Berlin Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin Wall"). Speaking
to Soviet officials in the aftermath of the crisis, Khrushchev asserted, "I
know for certain that Kennedy doesn't have a strong background, nor, generally
speaking, does he have the courage to stand up to a serious challenge." He
also told his son [Sergei](/wiki/Sergei_Khrushchev "Sergei Khrushchev") that
on Cuba, Kennedy "would make a fuss, make more of a fuss, and then agree."[5]

In January 1962, [US Army](/wiki/US_Army "US Army") General [Edward
Lansdale](/wiki/Edward_Lansdale "Edward Lansdale") described plans to
overthrow the Cuban government in a top-secret report (partially declassified
1989), addressed to Kennedy and officials involved with Operation Mongoose.[4]
CIA agents or "pathfinders" from the [Special Activities
Division](/wiki/Special_Activities_Division "Special Activities Division")
were to be infiltrated into Cuba to carry out sabotage and organization,
including radio broadcasts.[6] In February 1962, the US launched an [embargo
against Cuba](/wiki/United_States_embargo_against_Cuba "United States embargo
against Cuba"),[7] and Lansdale presented a 26-page, top-secret timetable for
implementation of the overthrow of the Cuban government, mandating guerrilla
operations to begin in August and September. "Open revolt and overthrow of the
Communist regime" would occur in the first two weeks of October.[4]

## Balance of
power[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Balance of power")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(October 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
When Kennedy ran for president in 1960, one of his key election issues was an
alleged "[missile gap](/wiki/Missile_gap "Missile gap")" with the Soviets
leading. In fact, the US led the Soviets by a wide margin that would only
increase. In 1961, the Soviets had only four [intercontinental ballistic
missiles](/wiki/Intercontinental_ballistic_missile "Intercontinental ballistic
missile") ([R-7 Semyorka](/wiki/R-7_Semyorka "R-7 Semyorka")). By October
1962, they may have had a few dozen, with some intelligence estimates as high
as 75.[8]

The U.S., on the other hand, had 170 ICBMs and was quickly building more. It
also had eight [_George Washington_](/wiki/George_Washington-class_submarine
"George Washington-class submarine")\- and [_Ethan Allen_
-class](/wiki/Ethan_Allen-class_submarine "Ethan Allen-class submarine")
[ballistic missile submarines](/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine "Ballistic
missile submarine"), with the capability to launch 16
[Polaris](/wiki/UGM-27_Polaris "UGM-27 Polaris") missiles, each with a range
of 2,500 nautical miles (4,600 km).

Khrushchev increased the perception of a missile gap when he loudly boasted to
the world that the Soviets were building missiles "like sausages" but Soviet
missiles' numbers and capabilities actually were nowhere close to his
assertions. The Soviet Union had [medium-range ballistic
missiles](/wiki/Medium-range_ballistic_missile "Medium-range ballistic
missile") in quantity, about 700 of them, but they were very unreliable and
inaccurate. The US had a considerable advantage in total number of nuclear
warheads (27,000 against 3,600) and in the technology required for their
accurate delivery.

The US also led in missile defensive capabilities, naval and air power; but
the Soviets had a 2-1 advantage in conventional ground forces, more pronounced
in field guns and tanks, particularly in the European theater.[8]

## Soviet deployment of missiles in
Cuba[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Soviet deployment of missiles in Cuba")]

In May 1961, Soviet Premier [Nikita Khrushchev](/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev
"Nikita Khrushchev") was persuaded by the idea of countering the US's growing
lead in developing and deploying strategic missiles by placing Soviet
intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Cuba, despite the misgivings of the
Soviet Ambassador in Havana, [Alexandr Ivanovich
Alexeyev](/wiki/Alexandr_Ivanovich_Alexeyev "Alexandr Ivanovich Alexeyev"),
who argued that Castro would not accept the deployment of the missiles.[9]
Khrushchev faced a strategic situation in which the US was perceived to have a
"splendid [first strike](/wiki/First_strike "First strike")" capability that
put the Soviet Union at a huge disadvantage. In 1962, the Soviets had only 20
[ICBMs](/wiki/ICBM "ICBM") capable of delivering nuclear warheads to the US
from inside the Soviet Union.[10] The poor accuracy and reliability of the
missiles raised serious doubts about their effectiveness. A newer, more
reliable generation of ICBMs would become operational only after 1965.[10]

Therefore, Soviet nuclear capability in 1962 placed less emphasis on ICBMs
than on medium and intermediate-range ballistic missiles ([MRBMs](/wiki/MRBM
"MRBM") and [IRBMs](/wiki/IRBM "IRBM")). The missiles could hit American
allies and most of [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska") from Soviet territory but
not the [Contiguous US](/wiki/Contiguous_US "Contiguous US"). Graham Allison,
the director of [Harvard University](/wiki/Harvard_University "Harvard
University")'s [Belfer Center for Science and International
Affairs](/wiki/Belfer_Center_for_Science_and_International_Affairs "Belfer
Center for Science and International Affairs"), points out, "The Soviet Union
could not right the nuclear imbalance by deploying new ICBMs on its own soil.
In order to meet the threat it faced in 1962, 1963, and 1964, it had very few
options. Moving existing nuclear weapons to locations from which they could
reach American targets was one."[11]

A second reason that Soviet missiles were deployed to Cuba was because
Khrushchev wanted to bring [West Berlin](/wiki/West_Berlin "West Berlin"),
controlled by the American, British and French within Communist [East
Germany](/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany"), into the Soviet orbit. The East
Germans and Soviets considered western control over a portion of
[Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin") a grave threat to East Germany. Khrushchev
made West Berlin the central battlefield of the Cold War. Khrushchev believed
that if the US did nothing over the missile deployments in Cuba, he could
muscle the West out of Berlin using said missiles as a deterrent to western
countermeasures in Berlin. If the US tried to bargain with the Soviets after
it became aware of the missiles, Khrushchev could demand trading the missiles
for West Berlin. Since Berlin was strategically more important than Cuba, the
trade would be a win for Khrushchev, as Kennedy recognized: "The advantage is,
from Khrushchev's point of view, he takes a great chance but there are quite
some rewards to it."[12]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Jupiter_on_its_launch_pad.jpg/220px-
Jupiter_on_its_launch_pad.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jupiter_on_its_launch_pad.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jupiter_on_its_launch_pad.jpg "Enlarge")

More than 100 US-built missiles having the capability to strike Moscow with
nuclear warheads were [deployed in Italy and
Turkey](/wiki/PGM-19_Jupiter#Military_deployment "PGM-19 Jupiter") in 1961.

Khrushchev was also reacting in part to the nuclear threat of obsolescent
[Jupiter](/wiki/PGM-19_Jupiter "PGM-19 Jupiter") intermediate-range ballistic
missiles that had been installed by the US in Turkey in April 1962.[8]

In early 1962, a group of Soviet military and missile construction specialists
accompanied an agricultural delegation to Havana. They obtained a meeting with
Cuban leader [Fidel Castro](/wiki/Fidel_Castro "Fidel Castro"). The Cuban
leadership had a strong expectation that the US would invade Cuba again and
enthusiastically approved the idea of installing nuclear missiles in Cuba.
However, according to another source, Castro objected to the missiles
deployment that would have made him look like a Soviet puppet, but he was
persuaded that missiles in Cuba would be an irritant to the US and help the
interests of the entire socialist camp.[13] Also, the deployment would include
short-range tactical weapons (with a range of 40 km, usable only against naval
vessels) that would provide a "nuclear umbrella" for attacks upon the island.

By May, Khrushchev and Castro agreed to place strategic nuclear missiles
secretly in Cuba. Like Castro, Khrushchev felt that a US invasion of Cuba was
imminent and that to lose Cuba would do great harm to the communists,
especially in Latin America. He said he wanted to confront the Americans "with
more than words.... the logical answer was missiles."[14]:29 The Soviets
maintained their tight secrecy, writing their plans longhand, which were
approved by [Rodion Malinovsky](/wiki/Rodion_Malinovsky "Rodion Malinovsky")
on July 4 and Khrushchev on July 7.

From the very beginning, the Soviets' operation entailed elaborate [denial and
deception](/wiki/Denial_and_deception "Denial and deception"), known as
"[maskirovka](/wiki/Russian_military_deception "Russian military
deception")".[15] All the planning and preparation for transporting and
deploying the missiles were carried out in the utmost secrecy, with only a
very few told the exact nature of the mission. Even the troops detailed for
the mission were given misdirection by being told that they were headed for a
cold region and being outfitted with ski boots, fleece-lined parkas, and other
winter equipment.[15] The Soviet codename was [Operation
Anadyr](/wiki/Operation_Anadyr "Operation Anadyr"). The [Anadyr
River](/wiki/Anadyr_River "Anadyr River") flows into the [Bering
Sea](/wiki/Bering_Sea "Bering Sea"), and Anadyr is also the
[capital](/wiki/Anadyr_\(town\) "Anadyr \(town\)") of [Chukotsky
District](/wiki/Chukotsky_District "Chukotsky District") and a bomber base in
the far eastern region. All the measures were meant to conceal the program
from both internal and external audiences.[15]

Specialists in missile construction under the guise of "machine operators,"
"irrigation specialists," and "agricultural specialists" arrived in July.[15]
A total of 43,000 foreign troops would ultimately be brought in.[16] Marshal
Sergei Biryuzov, chief of the Soviet Rocket Forces, led a survey team that
visited Cuba. He told Khrushchev that the missiles would be concealed and
camouflaged by palm trees.[8]

The Cuban leadership was further upset when in September, the [US
Congress](/wiki/US_Congress "US Congress") approved Joint Resolution 230,
which expressed Congress's resolve to prevent the creation of an externally-
supported military establishment.[17][18] On the same day, the US announced a
major military exercise in the Caribbean,
[PHIBRIGLEX-62](/wiki/Operation_Ortsac "Operation Ortsac"), which Cuba
denounced as a deliberate provocation and proof that the US planned to invade
Cuba.[18][19][_[unreliable
source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Identifying
reliable sources")_]

The Soviet leadership believed, based on its perception of Kennedy's lack of
confidence during the Bay of Pigs Invasion, that he would avoid confrontation
and accept the missiles as a _fait accompli_.[3]:1 On September 11, the Soviet
Union publicly warned that a US attack on Cuba or on Soviet ships that were
carrying supplies to the island would mean war.[4] The Soviets continued the
_Maskirovka_ program to conceal their actions in Cuba. They repeatedly denied
that the weapons being brought into Cuba were offensive in nature. On
September 7, [Soviet Ambassador to the United
States](/wiki/Soviet_Ambassador_to_the_United_States "Soviet Ambassador to the
United States") [Anatoly Dobrynin](/wiki/Anatoly_Dobrynin "Anatoly Dobrynin")
assured [United States Ambassador to the United
Nations](/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_the_United_Nations "United States
Ambassador to the United Nations") [Adlai Stevenson](/wiki/Adlai_Stevenson_II
"Adlai Stevenson II") that the Soviet Union was supplying only defensive
weapons to Cuba. On September 11, the [Telegrafnoe Agentstvo Sovetskogo
Soyuza](/wiki/Telegraph_Agency_of_the_Soviet_Union "Telegraph Agency of the
Soviet Union") (Soviet News Agency TASS) announced that the Soviet Union had
no need or intention to introduce offensive nuclear missiles into Cuba. On
October 13, Dobrynin was questioned by former Undersecretary of State [Chester
Bowles](/wiki/Chester_Bowles "Chester Bowles") about whether the Soviets
planned to put offensive weapons in Cuba. He denied any such plans.[18] On
October 17, Soviet embassy official Georgy Bolshakov brought President Kennedy
a personal message from Khrushchev reassuring him that "under no circumstances
would surface-to-surface missiles be sent to Cuba."[18]:494

As early as August 1962, the US suspected the Soviets of building missile
facilities in Cuba. During that month, its intelligence services gathered
information about sightings by ground observers of Russian-built
[MiG-21](/wiki/Mikoyan-Gurevich_MiG-21 "Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21") fighters and
[Il-28](/wiki/Ilyushin_Il-28 "Ilyushin Il-28") light bombers.
[U-2](/wiki/Lockheed_U-2 "Lockheed U-2") spyplanes found [S-75
Dvina](/wiki/S-75_Dvina "S-75 Dvina") (NATO designation _SA-2_) surface-to-air
missile sites at eight different locations. CIA director [John A.
McCone](/wiki/John_A._McCone "John A. McCone") was suspicious. Sending
antiaircraft missiles into Cuba, he reasoned, "made sense only if Moscow
intended to use them to shield a base for ballistic missiles aimed at the
United States."[20] On August 10, he wrote a memo to Kennedy in which he
guessed that the Soviets were preparing to introduce ballistic missiles into
Cuba.[8]

With important Congressional elections scheduled for November, the crisis
became enmeshed in American politics. On August 31, Senator [Kenneth
Keating](/wiki/Kenneth_Keating "Kenneth Keating") (R-New York), who received
his information from Cuban exiles in Florida, warned on the Senate floor that
the Soviet Union may be constructing a missile base in Cuba. He charged the
Kennedy administration of covering up a major threat to the US.[21] Air Force
General [Curtis LeMay](/wiki/Curtis_LeMay "Curtis LeMay") presented a pre-
invasion bombing plan to Kennedy in September, and spy flights and minor
military harassment from US forces at [Guantanamo Bay Naval
Base](/wiki/Guantanamo_Bay_Naval_Base "Guantanamo Bay Naval Base") were the
subject of continual Cuban diplomatic complaints to the US government.[4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/1962_Cuba_Missiles_%2830848755396%29.jpg/350px-1962_Cuba_Missiles_%2830848755396%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:1962_Cuba_Missiles_\(30848755396\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1962_Cuba_Missiles_\(30848755396\).jpg "Enlarge")

Map created by American intelligence showing Surface-to-Air Missile activity
in Cuba, September 5, 1962

The first consignment of [R-12](/wiki/R-12_\(missile\) "R-12 \(missile\)")
missiles arrived on the night of September 8, followed by a second on
September 16. The R-12 was a medium-range ballistic missile, capable of
carrying a [thermonuclear](/wiki/Thermonuclear "Thermonuclear") warhead.[22]
It was a single-stage, road-transportable, surface-launched, storable liquid
propellant fueled missile that could deliver a [megaton-
class](/wiki/TNT_equivalent "TNT equivalent") nuclear weapon.[23] The Soviets
were building nine sites — six for [R-12](/wiki/R-12_\(missile\) "R-12
\(missile\)") medium-range missiles (NATO designation _[SS-4
Sandal](/wiki/SS-4_Sandal "SS-4 Sandal")_) with an effective range of 2,000
kilometres (1,200 mi) and three for [R-14](/wiki/R-14_\(missile\) "R-14
\(missile\)") intermediate-range ballistic missiles (NATO designation _SS-5
Skean_) with a maximum range of 4,500 kilometres (2,800 mi).[24]

On October 7, Cuban President [Osvaldo Dorticós
Torrado](/wiki/Osvaldo_Dortic%C3%B3s_Torrado "Osvaldo Dorticós Torrado") spoke
at the [UN General Assembly](/wiki/UN_General_Assembly "UN General Assembly"):
"If... we are attacked, we will defend ourselves. I repeat, we have sufficient
means with which to defend ourselves; we have indeed our inevitable weapons,
the weapons, which we would have preferred not to acquire, and which we do not
wish to employ."

## Missiles
reported[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Missiles reported")]

The missiles in Cuba allowed the Soviets to target effectively most of the
Continental US. The planned arsenal was forty launchers. The Cuban populace
readily noticed the arrival and deployment of the missiles and hundreds of
reports reached Miami. US intelligence received countless reports, many of
dubious quality or even laughable, most of which could be dismissed as
describing defensive missiles.

Only five reports bothered the analysts. They described large trucks passing
through towns at night that were carrying very long canvas-covered cylindrical
objects that could not make turns through towns without backing up and
maneuvering. Defensive missiles could turn. The reports could not be
satisfactorily dismissed.[25]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/U2_Image_of_Cuban_Missile_Crisis.jpg/220px-U2_Image_of_Cuban_Missile_Crisis.jpg)](/wiki/File:U2_Image_of_Cuban_Missile_Crisis.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:U2_Image_of_Cuban_Missile_Crisis.jpg "Enlarge")

A U-2 reconnaissance photograph of Cuba, showing Soviet nuclear missiles,
their transports and tents for fueling and maintenance.

### Aerial images find Soviet
missiles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Aerial images find Soviet missiles")]

The United States had been sending [U-2](/wiki/Lockheed_U-2 "Lockheed U-2")
surveillance over Cuba since the failed Bay of Pigs Invasion.[26] The first
issue that led to a pause in reconnaissance flights took place on August 30,
when a U-2 operated by the U.S. Air Force's [Strategic Air
Command](/wiki/Strategic_Air_Command "Strategic Air Command") flew over
[Sakhalin Island](/wiki/Sakhalin "Sakhalin") in the [Soviet Far
East](/wiki/Soviet_Far_East "Soviet Far East") by mistake. The Soviets lodged
a protest and the US apologized. Nine days later, a [Taiwanese](/wiki/Taiwan
"Taiwan")-operated U-2[27][28] was lost over western China to an SA-2
[surface-to-air missile](/wiki/Surface-to-air_missile "Surface-to-air
missile"). US officials were worried that one of the Cuban or Soviet SAMs in
Cuba might shoot down a CIA U-2, initiating another international incident. In
a meeting with members of the Committee on Overhead Reconnaissance (COMOR) on
September 10, Secretary of State [Dean Rusk](/wiki/Dean_Rusk "Dean Rusk") and
National Security Advisor [McGeorge Bundy](/wiki/McGeorge_Bundy "McGeorge
Bundy") heavily restricted further U-2 flights over Cuban airspace. The
resulting lack of coverage over the island for the next five weeks became
known to historians as the "Photo Gap."[29] No significant U-2 coverage was
achieved over the interior of the island. US officials attempted to use a
[Corona photoreconnaissance satellite](/wiki/Corona_\(satellite\) "Corona
\(satellite\)") to obtain coverage over reported Soviet military deployments,
but imagery acquired over western Cuba by a Corona KH-4 mission on October 1
was heavily covered by clouds and haze and failed to provide any usable
intelligence.[30] At the end of September, Navy reconnaissance aircraft
photographed the Soviet ship _Kasimov_ , with large crates on its deck the
size and shape of [Il-28 light bomber](/wiki/Ilyushin_Il-28 "Ilyushin Il-28")
fuselages.[8]

In September 1962, analysts from the [Defense Intelligence
Agency](/wiki/Defense_Intelligence_Agency "Defense Intelligence Agency") (DIA)
noticed that Cuban surface-to-air missile sites were arranged in a pattern
similar to those used by the Soviet Union to protect its [ICBM](/wiki/ICBM
"ICBM") bases, leading DIA to lobby for the resumption of U-2 flights over the
island.[31] Although in the past the flights had been conducted by the CIA,
pressure from the Defense Department made the authority be transferred to the
Air Force.[8] Following the loss of a CIA U-2 over the Soviet Union in May
1960, it was thought that if another U-2 were shot down, an Air Force aircraft
arguably being used for a legitimate military purpose would be easier to
explain than a CIA flight.

When the reconnaissance missions were reauthorized on October 9, poor weather
kept the planes from flying. The US first obtained U-2 photographic evidence
of the missiles on October 14, when a [U-2](/wiki/Lockheed_U-2 "Lockheed U-2")
flight piloted by Major [Richard Heyser](/wiki/Richard_Heyser "Richard
Heyser") took 928 pictures on a path selected by
[DIA](/wiki/Defense_Intelligence_Agency "Defense Intelligence Agency")
analysts, capturing images of what turned out to be an SS-4 construction site
at [San Cristóbal](/wiki/San_Crist%C3%B3bal,_Cuba "San Cristóbal, Cuba"),
[Pinar del Río Province](/wiki/Pinar_del_R%C3%ADo_Province "Pinar del Río
Province") (now in [Artemisa Province](/wiki/Artemisa_Province "Artemisa
Province")), in western Cuba.[32]

### President
notified[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: President notified")]

On October 15, the CIA's [National Photographic Interpretation
Center](/wiki/National_Photographic_Interpretation_Center "National
Photographic Interpretation Center") (NPIC) reviewed the U-2 photographs and
identified objects that they interpreted as medium range ballistic missiles.
This identification was made, in part, on the strength of reporting provided
by [Oleg Penkovsky](/wiki/Oleg_Penkovsky "Oleg Penkovsky"), a [double
agent](/wiki/Double_agent "Double agent") in the [GRU](/wiki/GRU "GRU")
working for [CIA](/wiki/CIA "CIA") and [MI6](/wiki/MI6 "MI6"). Although he
provided no direct reports of the Soviet missile deployments to Cuba,
technical and doctrinal details of Soviet missile regiments that had been
provided by Penkovsky in the months and years prior to the Crisis helped NPIC
analysts correctly identify the missiles on U-2 imagery.[33]

That evening, the CIA notified the [Department of
State](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State "United States Department of
State") and at 8:30 pm [EDT](/wiki/Eastern_Daylight_Time "Eastern Daylight
Time"), Bundy chose to wait until the next morning to tell the President.
McNamara was briefed at midnight. The next morning, Bundy met with Kennedy and
showed him the U-2 photographs and briefed him on the CIA's analysis of the
images.[34] At 6:30 pm EDT, Kennedy convened a meeting of the nine members of
the National Security Council and five other key advisors,[35] in a group he
formally named the [Executive Committee of the National Security
Council](/wiki/EXCOMM "EXCOMM") (EXCOMM) after the fact on October 22 by the
National Security Action Memorandum 196.[36] Without informing the members of
EXCOMM, President Kennedy tape recorded all of their proceedings, and Sheldon
M. Stern, head of the Kennedy library transcribed some of them.[37][38]

### Responses
considered[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Responses considered")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/LeMay_Cuban_Missile_Crisis.jpg/220px-
LeMay_Cuban_Missile_Crisis.jpg)](/wiki/File:LeMay_Cuban_Missile_Crisis.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:LeMay_Cuban_Missile_Crisis.jpg "Enlarge")

President Kennedy meets in the Oval Office with General [Curtis
LeMay](/wiki/Curtis_LeMay "Curtis LeMay") and the reconnaissance pilots who
found the missile sites in Cuba.

The US had no plan in place because its intelligence had been convinced that
the Soviets would never install nuclear missiles in Cuba. The EXCOMM quickly
discussed several possible courses of action:[39]

  1. Do nothing: American vulnerability to Soviet missiles was not new.
  2. Diplomacy: Use diplomatic pressure to get the Soviet Union to remove the missiles.
  3. Secret approach: Offer Castro the choice of splitting with the Russians or being invaded.
  4. Invasion: Full force invasion of Cuba and overthrow of Castro.
  5. Air strike: Use the US Air Force to attack all known missile sites.
  6. Blockade: Use the US Navy to block any missiles from arriving in Cuba.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Cuban_Missile_Crisis_Game_Tree.svg/220px-
Cuban_Missile_Crisis_Game_Tree.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Cuban_Missile_Crisis_Game_Tree.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Cuban_Missile_Crisis_Game_Tree.svg "Enlarge")

As the article describes, both the US and the Soviet Union considered many
possible outcomes of their actions and threats during the crisis (Allison,
Graham T.; Zelikow, Philip D.). This [game tree](/wiki/Game_tree "Game tree")
models how both actors would have considered their decisions. It is broken
down into a simple form for basic understanding.

The [Joint Chiefs of Staff](/wiki/Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff "Joint Chiefs of
Staff") unanimously agreed that a full-scale attack and invasion was the only
solution. They believed that the Soviets would not attempt to stop the US from
conquering Cuba. Kennedy was skeptical:

> They, no more than we, can let these things go by without doing something.
> They can't, after all their statements, permit us to take out their
> missiles, kill a lot of Russians, and then do nothing. If they don't take
> action in Cuba, they certainly will in Berlin.[40]

Kennedy concluded that attacking Cuba by air would signal the Soviets to
presume "a clear line" to conquer Berlin. Kennedy also believed that US allies
would think of the country as "trigger-happy cowboys" who lost Berlin because
they could not peacefully resolve the Cuban situation.[41]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/McNamara_and_Kennedy.jpg/220px-
McNamara_and_Kennedy.jpg)](/wiki/File:McNamara_and_Kennedy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:McNamara_and_Kennedy.jpg "Enlarge")

President Kennedy and Secretary of Defense McNamara in an EXCOMM meeting.

The EXCOMM then discussed the effect on the strategic balance of power, both
political and military. The Joint Chiefs of Staff believed that the missiles
would seriously alter the military balance, but McNamara disagreed. An extra
40, he reasoned, would make little difference to the overall strategic
balance. The US already had approximately 5,000 strategic warheads,[42]:261
but the Soviet Union had only 300. McNamara concluded that the Soviets having
340 would not therefore substantially alter the strategic balance. In 1990, he
reiterated that "it made _no_ difference.... The military balance wasn't
changed. I didn't believe it then, and I don't believe it now."[43]

The EXCOMM agreed that the missiles would affect the _political_ balance.
Kennedy had explicitly promised the American people less than a month before
the crisis that "if Cuba should possess a capacity to carry out offensive
actions against the United States... the United States would act."[44]:674–681
Also, credibility among US allies and people would be damaged if the Soviet
Union appeared to redress the strategic balance by placing missiles in Cuba.
Kennedy explained after the crisis that "it would have politically changed the
balance of power. It would have appeared to, and appearances contribute to
reality."[45]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/CMC_Gromyko.jpg/220px-
CMC_Gromyko.jpg)](/wiki/File:CMC_Gromyko.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:CMC_Gromyko.jpg "Enlarge")

President Kennedy meets with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko in the
Oval Office (October 18, 1962)

On October 18, Kennedy met with Soviet Minister of Foreign Affairs, [Andrei
Gromyko](/wiki/Andrei_Gromyko "Andrei Gromyko"), who claimed the weapons were
for defensive purposes only. Not wanting to expose what he already knew and to
avoid panicking the American public,[46] Kennedy did not reveal that he was
already aware of the missile buildup.[47]

By October 19, frequent U-2 spy flights showed four operational sites.[48] On
the night of October 19 at 23:56 a helicopter from USS Essex CVS-9 squadron
HSS-2 crashed into the Gulf of Mexico. Lt. Cmdr. James Robert Hughes and AM-3
George Blythe perished. Their bodies were never recovered. On October 22, 1962
a second helicopter crashed into the Gulf, that also was from HSS-2 stationed
on the Essex. Lost that night were Lt. Cmdr. Witkowski and Enlisted Serviceman
50 AZ Murphy. The details of the deaths of October 19, 1962 have never been
provided to the families affected. There are numerous rumors that exist from
bad storms, Soviet interference with the flight, or a one-way suicide recon
mission. However, the most consistently repeated accounts from on deck
witnesses indicate that the helicopter on October 19 was "shot
down."[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

## Operational
plans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Operational plans")]

Two Operational Plans (OPLAN) were considered. OPLAN 316 envisioned a full
invasion of Cuba by Army and Marine units, supported by the Navy following Air
Force and naval airstrikes. However, Army units in the US would have had
trouble fielding mechanized and logistical assets, and the US Navy could not
supply enough amphibious shipping to transport even a modest armored
contingent from the Army.

OPLAN 312, primarily an Air Force and Navy carrier operation, was designed
with enough flexibility to do anything from engaging individual missile sites
to providing air support for OPLAN 316's ground forces.[49]

##
Blockade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Blockade")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/P-2H_Neptune_over_Soviet_ship_Oct_1962.jpg/220px-P-2H_Neptune_over_Soviet_ship_Oct_1962.jpg)](/wiki/File:P-2H_Neptune_over_Soviet_ship_Oct_1962.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:P-2H_Neptune_over_Soviet_ship_Oct_1962.jpg "Enlarge")

A US Navy [P-2H Neptune](/wiki/P-2_Neptune "P-2 Neptune") of VP-18 flying over
a Soviet cargo ship with crated [Il-28s](/wiki/Ilyushin_Il-28 "Ilyushin
Il-28") on deck during the Cuban Crisis.[50]

Kennedy met with members of EXCOMM and other top advisers throughout October
21, considering two remaining options: an air strike primarily against the
Cuban missile bases or a naval blockade of Cuba.[47] A full-scale invasion was
not the administration's first option. McNamara supported the naval
[blockade](/wiki/Blockade "Blockade") as a strong but limited military action
that left the US in control. However, the term "blockade" was problematic.
According to [international law](/wiki/International_law "International law"),
a blockade is an [act of war](/wiki/Casus_belli "Casus belli"), but the
Kennedy administration did not think that the Soviets would be provoked to
attack by a mere blockade.[51] Additionally, legal experts at the [State
Department](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State "United States Department
of State") and [Justice Department](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice
"United States Department of Justice") concluded that a declaration of war
could be avoided if another legal justification, based on the [Rio
Treaty](/wiki/Inter-American_Treaty_of_Reciprocal_Assistance "Inter-American
Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance") for defense of the Western Hemisphere, was
obtained from a resolution by a two-thirds vote from the members or the
[Organization of American States](/wiki/Organization_of_American_States
"Organization of American States") (OAS).[52]

[Admiral](/wiki/Admiral "Admiral") [Anderson](/wiki/George_Whelan_Anderson_Jr.
"George Whelan Anderson Jr."), [Chief of Naval
Operations](/wiki/Chief_of_Naval_Operations "Chief of Naval Operations") wrote
a position paper that helped Kennedy to differentiate between what they termed
a "quarantine"[53] of offensive weapons and a blockade of all materials,
claiming that a classic blockade was not the original intention. Since it
would take place in international waters, Kennedy obtained the approval of the
OAS for military action under the hemispheric defense provisions of the Rio
Treaty:

> Latin American participation in the quarantine now involved two Argentine
> destroyers which were to report to the U.S. Commander South Atlantic
> [COMSOLANT] at Trinidad on November 9. An Argentine submarine and a Marine
> battalion with lift were available if required. In addition, two Venezuelan
> destroyers (Destroyers ARV D-11 Nueva Esparta" and "ARV D-21 Zulia") and one
> submarine (Caribe) had reported to COMSOLANT, ready for sea by November 2.
> The Government of Trinidad and Tobago offered the use of
> [Chaguaramas](/wiki/Chaguaramas,_Trinidad "Chaguaramas, Trinidad") Naval
> Base to warships of any OAS nation for the duration of the "quarantine." The
> Dominican Republic had made available one escort ship. Colombia was reported
> ready to furnish units and had sent military officers to the U.S. to discuss
> this assistance. The Argentine Air Force informally offered three
> [SA-16](/wiki/Grumman_SA-16 "Grumman SA-16") aircraft in addition to forces
> already committed to the "quarantine" operation.[54]

> This initially was to involve a naval blockade against offensive weapons
> within the framework of the [Organization of American
> States](/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of American
> States") and the [Rio Treaty](/wiki/Inter-
> American_Treaty_of_Reciprocal_Assistance "Inter-American Treaty of
> Reciprocal Assistance"). Such a blockade might be expanded to cover all
> types of goods and air transport. The action was to be backed up by
> surveillance of Cuba. The CNO's scenario was followed closely in later
> implementing the "quarantine."

On October 19, the EXCOMM formed separate working groups to examine the air
strike and blockade options, and by the afternoon most support in the EXCOMM
shifted to the blockade option. However, reservations about the plan continued
to be voiced as late as the October 21, the paramount concern being that once
the blockade was put into effect, the Soviets would rush to complete some of
the missiles. Consequently, the US could find itself bombing operational
missiles if blockade failed to force Khrushchev to remove the missiles already
on the island.[55]

### Speech to the
nation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cuban_Missile_Crisis&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Speech to the nation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/President_Kennedy_signs_Cuba_quarantine_proclamation%2C_23_October_1962.jpg/220px-
President_Kennedy_signs_Cuba_quarantine_proclamation%2C_23_October_1962.jpg)](/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_signs_Cuba_quarantine_proclamation,_23_October_1962.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_signs_Cuba_quarantine_proclamation,_23_October_1962.jpg
"Enlarge")

President Kennedy signs the Proclamation for Interdiction of the Delivery of
Offensive Weapons to Cuba at the [Oval Office](/wiki/Oval_Office "Oval
Office") on October 23, 1962.[56]

At 3:00 pm EDT on October 22, President Kennedy formally established the
Executive Committee (EXCOMM) with National Security Action Memorandum (NSAM)
196. At 5:00 pm, he met with Congressional leaders who contentiously opposed a
blockade and demanded a stronger response. In [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow"),
Ambassador [Foy D. Kohler](/wiki/Foy_D._Kohler "Foy D. Kohler") briefed
Khrushchev on the pending blockade and Kennedy's speech to the nation.
Ambassadors around the world gave notice to non-[Eastern
Bloc](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc "Eastern Bloc") leaders. Before the speech, US
delegations met with Canadian Prime Minister [John
Diefenbaker](/wiki/John_Diefenbaker "John Diefenbaker"), British Prime
Minister [Harold Macmillan](/wiki/Harold_Macmillan "Harold Macmillan"), [West
German](/wiki/West_German "West German") [Chancellor](/wiki/Chancellor
"Chancellor") [Konrad Adenauer](/wiki/Konrad_Adenauer "Konrad Adenauer"), and
French President [Charles de Gaulle](/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle "Charles de
Gaulle") to brief them on the US intelligence and their proposed response. All
were supportive of the U.S. position.[57]

Shortly before his speech, Kennedy called former President [Dwight
Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_Eisenhower "Dwight Eisenhower").[58] Kennedy's
conversation with the former President also revealed that the two were
conspiring during the Cuban Missile Crisis.[59]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  [Address on the Buildup of Arms in Cuba](/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg "File:John F Kennedy Address on the Buildup of Arms in Cuba.ogg") ![](data:image/png,%89PNG%0D%0A%1A%0A%00%00%00%0DIHDR%00%00%00%01%00%00%00%01%08%02%00%00%00%90wS%DE%00%00%00%01sRGB%00%AE%CE%1C%E9%00%00%00%09pHYs%00%00%0B%13%00%00%0B%13%01%00%9A%9C%18%00%00%00%07tIME%07%DB%0B%0A%17%041%80%9B%E7%F2%00%00%00%19tEXtComment%00Created%20with%20GIMPW%81%0E%17%00%00%00%0CIDAT%08%D7c%60%60%60%00%00%00%04%00%01'4'%0A%00%00%00%00IEND%AEB%60%82)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a9/John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg) Kennedy addressing the nation on October 22, 1962 about the buildup of arms on Cuba

* * *

"Wikipedia:Media help")._  
![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png) | [Wikisource](/wiki/Wikisource "Wikisource") has original text related to this article: **[Cuban Missile Crisis](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis "wikisource:Cuban Missile Crisis")**
